children.value: Welcome to your first Python library - NumPy! NumPy is the fundamental package for numerical operations with Python
useful linear algebra, Fourier transform, and random number capabilities
Let’s get you started with the basics! In this notebook we will cover
Inspecting an array with slicing and indexing
A common convention you might encounter is to rename
on import to shorten it for the many times we will be calling on

block of memory, holding entries of a given type (and hence fixed size). The entries are laid out in memory according to the shape, or list of dimension sizes. Let’s start by creating an array from a list of integers and taking a look at it,
We can inspect the number of dimensions our array is organized along with
, and how long each of these dimensions are with
So our 1-dimensional array has a shape of
along that dimension! Finally we can check out the underlying type of our underlying data,
Now, let’s expand this with a new data type, and by using a list of lists we can grow the dimensions of our array!
And as before we can use
to discover how many dimensions of what lengths are making up our array of floats.
NumPy also provides helper functions for generating arrays of data to save you typing for regularly spaced data. Don’t forget your Python indexing rules!
creates a range of values in the interval
evenly spaced values over the range
NumPy, creating sequences of values and adding them together requires writing a lot of manual loops, just like one would do in C/C++:

a = list(range(5, 10))
b = [3 + i * 1.5 / 4 for i in range(5)]

a, b

result = []
for x, y in zip(a, b):
    result.append(x + y)
print(result)
That is very verbose and not very intuitive. Using NumPy this becomes:
Many major mathematical operations operate in the same way. They perform an element-by-element calculation of the two arrays.
These arrays must be the same shape!

jupyter_data.evalue: operands could not be broadcast together with shapes (5,) (6,)

children.value: NumPy provides us access to some useful constants as well - remember you should never be typing these in manually! Other libraries such as SciPy and MetPy have their own set of constants that are more domain specific.
You can use these for classic calculations you might be familiar with! Here we can create a range

t = np.arange(0, 2 * np.pi + np.pi / 4, np.pi / 4)
t
NumPy also has math functions that can operate on arrays. Similar to the math operations, these greatly simplify and speed up these operations. Let’s start with calculating

children.html: sin⁡(t)\sin(t)sin(t)

Check out NumPy's list of mathematical functions
We can convert between degrees and radians with only NumPy, by hand
We are similarly provided algorithms for operations including integration, bulk summing, and cumulative summing.
We can use integer indexing to reach into our arrays and pull out individual elements. Let’s make a toy 2-d array to explore. Here we create a 12-value

Finally, a few more examples of this notation before reintroducing our 2-d array

b[:3]  # similarly, the same as our b[0:3]
This entire syntax can be extended to each dimension of multidimensional arrays.

In this notebook we introduced NumPy and the

that is so crucial to the entirety of the scientific Python community ecosystem. We created some arrays, used some of NumPy’s own mathematical functions to manipulate them, and then introduced the world of NumPy indexing and selecting for even multi-dimensional arrays.

This notebook is the gateway to nearly every other Pythia resource here. This information is crucial for understanding SciPy, pandas, xarray, and more. Continue into NumPy to explore some more intermediate and advanced topics!
